This time every year, there is a lot of discussion around the mil rate and what it means to the taxpayers in our community. Based on discussions from the most recent Town Council workshop, the chart below shows a few different tax scenarios of annual tax increases. These calculations do take into account the Homestead Exemption. The 1.16% mil rate increase is based on the school department's most recent budget proposal, which does not include COVID expenses that the schools will incur. We have asked for those COVID costs to be considered separately. The 1.97% mil rate increase below reflects the tax increase if the COVID costs are funded by the taxpayers. The 1.5% mil rate calculations represent a compromise roughly in the middle.

If the mil rate is increased by 1.97%, homes valued at $280K or less will see a reduction to their tax bill. If the mil rate increases by 1.5%, homes valued at $360K or less will see a reduction to their tax bill. If the tax rate is increased to 1.16%, homes valued at $455K or less will see a reduction to their tax bill.

Given the growing concern about the potential spread of the COVID-19 virus across the state of Maine and throughout our nation, we have determined that the best course of action is to close our schools now.
We have come to the realization that closing our schools now and taking this time to “flatten the curve” would be the best course of action to ensure the ongoing safety of all of our students and staff. Please know that this decision does not come lightly, and we completely understand that cancelling school may present many challenges for you.

On Friday, March 20, we will reassess and make decisions about ongoing closures or the ability to reopen, and we will communicate that information to you. At this time, the decision to close schools is a local decision based on what we are feeling is in the best interest of our community. An update on how we plan to support the continuation of learning will be shared via a separate communication to you on Monday, March 16.

Thank you for your understanding during this extremely challenging time.

Scarborough Public Schools are so fortunate to partner with Junior Achievement and offer programming across our schools. Currently, there is a need for 3-6 volunteers at Scarborough Middle School for a 6th grade JA in a Day program, "It’s My Business" on March 13. All materials and support are provided! Email Pamela (pbennett@jamaine.org) if you can help!

Here are answers to common questions that you might be wondering about:
Will I have to develop lesson plans? No, Junior Achievement provides a program curriculum, along with a volunteer guide to facilitate the process. Your role is to introduce hands-on activities that demonstrate key concepts, then share your work and life experience with students.
Will I receive training? Yes, a member of the Junior Achievement team will conduct training to ensure you are prepared for your classroom experience.
Do I have to have teaching experience to volunteer? No, just a willingness to prepare for each session and a desire to work with students.

post_text: Two Middle School teachers, Molly Fahan and Will Cabana, received their National Board Certification as of December 7! For those who are not familiar, the National Board Five Core Propositions and Standards describe what accomplished teachers should know and be able to do to have a positive impact on student learning. National Board Certification identifies teachers who meet those standards through a performance-based, peer-reviewed series of assessment components. Issued by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, the certification takes 1 to 3 years to complete and is the highest professional certification a teacher can earn. Congratulations to Molly and Will!
